It wasnâ€™t to be and weâ€™re now running out of games whereCity conceivablymight not win. Iâ€™d rule out the home games. As good as Newcastleâ€™s form is and however motivated Gerrard might be, I canâ€™t see Newcastle or Villa getting anythingat the Ethiad. Which leaves Wolves away and West Ham away. Wolves seem to have decided European football isnâ€™t for them and ended the season early, so the London Stadium does seem like the only real possible candidate for a result. Which makes Thursday night absolutely key. Win it and West Ham will put out a second string against City, 3 days before the Europa league final. Lose on Thursday and West Ham will be desperate for points to be back in the Europa league next season. What happens on Thursday could be the decisive factor in who wins the title. Of course, it might all be for nothing. Thereâ€™s no guarantee of Liverpool winning their remaining 4 games and even a full strengthWest Ham wouldbe underdogs against this City team. But as much as Iâ€™d love to see West Ham win the Europa League, Iâ€™ll be hoping they crashout on Thursday and give City a proper match.Mike, LFC, London READ MORE: Man City show shower mentality in Leeds paper storm to douse Liverpool hopes  Kloppâ€™s gambleYouâ€™ve got to hand it to Klopp today. He took a gamble with that line up but it paid off. Ultimately it means Trent got a full week off and Fabinho, Salah and ManÃ© didnâ€™t have to play a full 90 minutes. You could see a couple of times Klopp lost his sh*t on the touch line as our forwards wasted a few big chances and fair play to him. Newcastle looked decent and forced us into bringing on our best players to try and contain the game. I think a lot of their players have an awful lot to play for this season so itâ€™s no surprise theyâ€™re working so hard. I just hope they do something similar against Man City because they couldâ€™ve snatched a point today and you never knowâ€¦ Robertson is such a class act. Just tears up and down that left side for 90 minutes every three days and doesnâ€™t seem to show any signs of fatigue or complacency. This has possibly been his best season for Liverpool which was hard to imagine when heâ€™s already had some outstanding seasons. Credit to BT Sport too for trying to create some controversy from the least controversial tackle of the game in the build up to the goal. It wasnâ€™t the most exciting match they did well to get so much talking out of such a non-event.Minty, LFC Newcastle assessment As a Magpie, the best thing I can say about that match is that it had absolutely no bearing on the relegation battle, which I wouldnâ€™t have believed in December. Liverpool are irritating AF, but theyâ€™re just so good. It was like they had an extra man on the pitch the entire 90 minutes. Liverpool easily did to us what weâ€™ve recently been just managing to do to other teams: press hard enough to deny them time on the ball and take at least one of the chances on offer. More often than not, our passes were between stationary players, leaving us flat-footed and vulnerable to Liverpoolâ€™s press. They nearly marked St. Maximin out of the match, collapsing blind alleys around him time after time. Almironâ€™s speed counted for little against Liverpoolâ€™s midfield and defense, and the like rest of the forward and midfield lines, he simply was not as good as the opponents he faced. Even Guimaraes, though Bruno might have done better with more speed and touch around him in midfield. Shelveyâ€™s immobility in particular was a real handicap. You canâ€™t really fault the way we defended. Krafth, who couldnâ€™t cope with the pace, was blown after 65 minutes; it was amazing he made 84 without us conceding again. A brave, but revealing performance. Lascelles again did quite well in defense, replacing Schar. Burn was immense, as usual. I canâ€™t think of a situation he didnâ€™t deal with well; he was standing still for the goal, but once the ball was past him, there was little he couldâ€™ve done. Heck, I was pleased that we managed to put the ball in the net at all, even if it was offside. All things must pass, and 0-1 to Liverpool is about the best imaginable way for our home win streak to have ended. I wouldâ€™ve loved, it, loved it if weâ€™d put a dent in their title hopes, though.Chris C, Toon Army DC Newcastle positivity The Newcastle-Liverpool game just finished and have to applaud Newcastle for sticking to a much more positive game plan than the one Everton put in place. Howe has done a great job. A lot of forward pressing kept Liverpool under pressure. And they managed to keep Liverpoolâ€™s opportunities to a minimum without a low block of two banks of 4 or 5. And apart from a couple of pushes in the game, it was a relatively clean game with no gamesmanship. Heck, they did much better than Villareal. Hopefully Emery wasnâ€™t watching and getting a few tips. What a contrast between two English managers in Howe and Lampard. Newcastle are going to do well next season.Paul McDevitt  Crystal Palace thoughts Had my hair cut an hour before kickoff in Soton v Crystal Palace. Donâ€™t worry, my hair is probably still longer than yours. Not sure this is sustainable as a means of ensuring a Palace win but needs must. *On Monday night, the Eagles struggled through a feisty 0-0 draw with Leeds United, in which the referee took a very lenient approach towards some of the crunching tackles that flew in. Predictably, Wilfried Zaha was the most often targeted, on the receiving end of several fouls that merited yellow cards (but did not), only for Kalvin Phillips to call him a diver after the match. Iâ€™m obligated to point out that in the three seasons since VAR was introduced, the only occasion on which a referee decided Zaha had dived, he was forced to overturn his decision and award a kick from the penalty mark. We can but speculate on what might have happened today with one of Phillipsâ€™s teammates had they been previously dissuaded from flying into the sort of challenges where people end up getting hurt. *The after-effects of Mondayâ€™s game took their toll on the Palace team, with Patrick Vieira taking the bold decision to put Zaha on the bench from the start. This decision looked to have backfired early on when Soton took the lead, yet another goal Vieiraâ€™s team have conceded from a corner. After that, Palace dominated the game. Jeffrey Schlupp found plenty of space behind the Saints defence. as his side created several good chances. The equaliser arrived courtesy of a fantastic move finished off by Eberechi Eze. Itâ€™s been a long road back from his horrific injury, heâ€™s had limited playing time and not really shown his full potential when he has played. That said, he has had to learn new roles in the team and his commitment has never been in question while we acknowledge he is a work in progress. Iâ€™m really pleased for him to get his goal today. *Shortly after the goal, enter Zaha. Appropriately enough for todayâ€™s opposition, I canâ€™t think of a player who has that important to his team and that fun to watch since Matthew Le Tissier in his pomp. For clarity I am talking exclusively about his playing career. Combined with the later introduction of Michael Olise, Vieira made changes knowing full well the game was there to be won. Inevitably, it was the man who can legitimately claim to be Palaceâ€™s greatest ever player who settled the tie with a moment of trademark magic. Readers with long memories may recall the time Zaha was sent off for sarcastically clapping a referee, and James Ward-Prowse celebrating the decision like heâ€™d scored a goal. It shows just how much more mature Zaha is than you or I that he didnâ€™t celebrate in Ward-Prowseâ€™s face, Martin Keown-style. Or do a Jurgen Klinsmann dive. *Speaking of that ridiculous officiating line in the sand, prior to that red card, Zaha had scored four goals in 23 appearances; he then scored six in his next 13; when he was sent from the field against Tottenham earlier this season, I suggested a similar effect may take place. Sure enough, having scored five goals before the Boxing Day game, he has scored seven since returning from suspension (and AFCON), which makes this his most prolific season in the top flight. *This was the first time all season that Palace have recovered from a losing position to win a game, and remarkably the first game theyâ€™ve won by a single goal. The result doesnâ€™t really affect too much in the grand scheme of things; all either side is playing for is exactly where they will finish in the midtable pack. However, this was an important demonstration from Vieira that his side can carve out results when their attacking verve doesnâ€™t immediately blow teams away. *With this result, Palace match their points total from 34 games last season, but with a goal difference of+3 compared to -20. While this matters little in the bigger picture, just as the number of times theyâ€™ve won the xG battle, it does indicate how much more attacking they have been this year. By coincidence, their next match sees them face Roy Hodgsonâ€™s Watford, a fixture that will see the Hornets relegated if they donâ€™t win. *There is a lot of noise suggesting Aaron Wan-Bissaka could be set to re-join Palace on loan next season. As often as possible during his time at Old Trafford Iâ€™ve been saying heâ€™s not good enough for Manchester United and they should send him back, and people are starting to think my motivations are self-interested. Despite what is said about him, Wan-Bissaka is a great player; however, he established himself thus in a team that did a lot of defending, where he was able to show off his incredible tackling. The trouble is, he joined a Manchester United team wanting their right-back to be a bit more attacking than he would be for Roy Hodgson, which isnâ€™t his strongest suit. The trouble is, at no point did it occur to anyone at Manchester United to teach him how to play the way they needed him to. *When Burnley announced they had terminated Sean Dycheâ€™s contract, I was one of the very few people to suggest that it wasnâ€™t a mistake and that Dycheâ€™s playing style had held the Clarets back. That an inexperienced manager has taken over and simply encouraged his team to attack cannot be a coincidence.Ed Quoththeraven   â€˜Childishâ€™ Leeds If anyone ever needed reminding why football fans have a reputation for being boorish, immature, intellectually challenged halfwits, thank you Leeds for doing the honours. Launching scrunched up paper on the pitch and at players. Wow. Been a long time since Iâ€™ve been awestruck at something so idiotic, childish and pointless.Marc, MCFC,Bolton  League One promotion This is it. 45 rounds of football, and itâ€™s all come down to this. As a Wycombe fan, writing this as heâ€™s traveling to the match. Iâ€™m bricking it. First it speaks to the quality of the league, that only one team in both the relegation, and promotion spots, is mathematically secure (well, in the case of Crewe, insecure) Three teams can win the league, three teams can get automatic promotion, six teams are involved in the chase to ensure they have playoffs to play after today, whilst five teams at the Bottom have everything to give today. Thought I would give my views on the promotion candidates and their matches, since honestly Iâ€™m just nervous and need to get it off my chest Wigan Vs Shrewsbury â€“ wonâ€™t imagine any surprises for Wigan. Should be a fairly easy, if not nervous, victory and trophy for them. Rotherham Vs Gillingham â€“ theoretically an easier match than Wiganâ€™s, but they need Wigan to lose or draw to have a chance at winning that title. Should secure the automatic promotion though MK Dons Vs Plymouth â€“ this is the big match today, MK want the chance of automatic if Rotherham lose or draw, whilst Plymouth need a win to ensure they stay ahead of Wycombe. Could honestly go either way, both teams have everything to gain and nothing to lose, so should be a very interesting match Sunderland Vs Morecambe â€“ As much as I donâ€™t want to admit it, Sunderland should have this. As a Wycombe fan Iâ€™m split between wanting them to lose now, or possibly getting them in the playoffs and having another chance to rile up Sunderland fans again. Wycombe Vs Burton â€“ Theoretically a good game, and Wycombe have absolutely nothing to lose. Can theoretically overtake Plymouth even if they win, since we are only 2 behind on GD and we beat them in the H2H comparison. Weâ€™ll have a packed out away stand which hopefully will help. Iâ€™m loving today. Iâ€™ll take a day like this over the Premier League any day. This has been an incredible competitive league with alot of amazing matches, and win or lose, Iâ€™ve loved it allDaragh Milsom

Content_title: Why is Lampard â€˜not getting even more stickâ€™ at Everton? Silent Man City and more mailsâ€¦
Contents: Should Frank Lampard be getting more stick at Everton or has it gone too far? Plus, a quiet Tuesday night at the Etihad,Robo Pep, Arsenal relegated andskillsâ€¦ Send your thoughts totheeditor@football365.comâ€¦ A quiet Tuesday night in Manchester Rare that I have time to watch a non-Liverpool game these days but my wife and youngest son are in hospital (theyâ€™re fine, donâ€™t worry) so I had time on my hands. Amazing game, of course, but did anyone else think the crowd was incrediblyflat? Iâ€™m not one get into a â€œMy dadâ€™s harder than your dadâ€ argument, so Iâ€™m not coming at this comparingCity to Liverpool or anything. Itâ€™s not a criticism, just an observation. Man City have some incrediblesupporters. Go back and watch the highlights of their playoff semi finals and final from division 2 and the atmosphere is fantastic. When the goals go in, fans are going ballistic. Last night, that just wasnâ€™t the case. I watched thesecond goal go in,to go 2-0 up,after 10 minutes,against Real Madrid in the Champions League semi final and I couldnâ€™t believe it. It was like it was a Premier League game against Watford. In most stadiums, youâ€™d expect theplace to then be absolutely bouncing following the goal. Non-stop singing,non-stop cheering. It wasnâ€™t the case at all. It was quiet. There was a section of the crowd you could hear throughout the game but the majority were pretty quiet for a game of that magnitude. Is this purely the result of the day-tripper type fans that larger clubs attract now? I mean donâ€™t get me wrong, some Premier League atmospheresare flat as anything, Anfield included, but most fans get up for it for the big games. Speaking of fans, City fans booing the theme of the tournament that their club is desperate to win remains extremely silly. Itâ€™s like a teenager who thinks heâ€™s being edgy for some minor act of rebellion, when actually they just come across like a knob. Seriously, youâ€™re not some hard done by underdog, give it a rest.Mike, LFC, London  Robo PepJust a quick rebuttal to Mark (MCFC) â€” I am indeed one of those people that find watching City suffocate the life out of teams by flooding the midfield dull as ditchwater. And I think last nightâ€™s madness of a game and the excitement it generated just shows how dull City normally are â€” do you think Pep is happy about the lack of control City had in that game? Or do you think he would have much preferred the usual 95% City possession followed by a pull back for one of the 450 midfielders to score a couple? Basically City got involved in a proper game, a real ding-dong last night, not the usual sterile game they usually play where they are 4-0 up after 20 minutes. I think I speak for all of football in requesting Keegan comes back after Pep has gone.Dan, London  The ironyâ€¦ â€¦of Fenandinho being outwitted by Vinicius Jr and failing to make his customary tactical foul on the halfway line was particularly delicious last nightSteve Leeds â€“ really looking forward to playing City next â€“ hopefully they will be as profligate in front of goal as they were last night â€“ Iâ€™d take 0-4 right now PS Yorkshire Pingu â€“ thatâ€™s genius  What is the point of Everton?Questions this morning on why people suddenly want Everton to be relegated prompted me to ask the questionâ€¦ what is the point of Everton? Everton have been ever present in the Premier League and in that time (this is the 30thseason) they have never finished in the top 3 (and obviously never in the bottom 3). 29 previous seasons of never competing for the title and never being relegated. In that time Norwich, Nottingham Forest, Aston Villa, Blackburn, Newcastle and Leicester have all finished in the top 3 but not Everton. They have reached 1 FA Cup final in the last 25 years and havenâ€™t reached the League Cup final since the 1980s. Everton have never actually won the League Cup which puts them in the shadow of such luminaries as Oxford United, Stoke, Swansea, QPR, Swindon, Luton, Birmingham and West Brom. Since the start of the Premier League both Middlesbrough and Fulham have reached European finals but Everton havenâ€™t. Coventry City, Blackburn, Newcastle and Sunderland have all had a Premier League top scorer but Everton havenâ€™t. They havenâ€™t had a Player of the Year since the mid-1980s and have never had a Young Player of the Year. The sun rises and sets, players come and go, Prime Ministers are convicted of criminal offences and pandemics threaten our existence but through it all Everton finish mid-table. Always and forever mid-table. I mean, seriously, what is the point of Everton?Micki Attridge  Lack of leadershipâ€¦Before getting to my main point, a shout out to City and RM for an entertaining game last night. To Markâ€™s point, as a neutral it was definitely fun to watch. City should have had a couple more â€“ at least. And a rebuttal to James EFC. It seems Evertonions keep making the same point without hearing what is being said or the rationality of it. So Iâ€™ll say it again. If Liverpool are buying players from other premier league clubs, then those other premier league clubs must have been able to convince those players to play for them. The point? Everton could equally have signed said players no? So, to be clear. If Hull could find Robertson, Newcastle Wijnaldum, Southampton Mane and Van Dyke, Wolves Jota, for example, why couldnâ€™t Everton?Liverpool didnâ€™t bring those players into the Premier League. Everton have been absolute b*ll*cks at scouting talent for a long time. Itâ€™s got nothing to do with the fact the players would prefer to go to Liverpool â€“ of course they would right now â€“ but that wasnâ€™t the case when Liverpool were building their team looking for hidden gems to fit their system. So rather than see big bad Liverpool as the cause of Evertonâ€™s problems or to excuse the ultimately pitiful time wasting, focus on why when Everton did decide to play, they could play and why those same players have not turned up like that away from home for so long. Itâ€™s because, like their fans, they are blaming everything and everyone else for their fate rather than standing up to be counted. Thatâ€™s why Everton are in such trouble, why neutrals donâ€™t like whining Frank â€“ who isnâ€™t showing any leadership either.Paul McDevitt  Lampard vs BenitezHello As a plastic LFC fan, I have a soft spot for Rafa & am not a great fan of Frank Lampard, so Iâ€™m clearly biased, but Iâ€™m not sure why Frank L is not getting even more stick than he has been. No real â€˜new manager bounceâ€™ and his record is even worse than Rafaâ€™s: Rafael Benitez@ Everton: W 7 D 5 L 10 Frank Lampard@ Everton W 5 D 1 L9KC, Cork  Frank hateâ€¦Yeah I donâ€™t really get the hate for Frank at F365 towers. Anti-English/British sentiment is fairly common on the site. Mainly from Johnny N. Now Iâ€™m all for a wee bit of anti-English sentiment. My recent mails re: geo politics and football caused quite a stir amongst the Queensâ€™ loyal followers. I just donâ€™t really understand the hatred of the English when it comes to football. I like English football. Hell I even like the English football team AND its manager. I never thought id say those words in my life. As with almost all leagues in Europe/the world, the majority of managers within that league, tend to be from that country. These people often know the clubs, know the language, have the visa, know the dressing rooms, understand the league, understand the club/expectations etc etc. It seems a fairly logical place to start. Unless there is some clear managerial genius available from Dusseldorf for a decent price that is willing to go to a relegation troubled borefest like Everton, then youâ€™re flipping a coin really. Do you want to avoid relegation by playing total football, or do you want to avoid relegation by old school English â€œget faaaaaaacking stuck in you muggggsâ€ tactics. With a piss poor team like Everton, either way seems as likely as the other to produce success. Franks way doesnâ€™t seem to be working. Iâ€™m not sure the â€œinsert hipster Dutch coachâ€™s name hereâ€ way would work either. Better the devil you know perhaps? David Moyes didnâ€™t deserve that West Ham job. Yet hes created a Champions League challenging team. Sometimes it works. Steven Gerard probably didnâ€™t deserve that Villa job. Sometimes it kind of works. Frank Lampard didnâ€™t deserve that Everton Job. Sometimes it doesnâ€™t work. You are as likely to get the same above results with Frank Lampard from London as you are with Frunk Vun Lampardstank from Hamburg. No doubt all the football hipsters would say otherwise.Letâ€™s not act like any of the managers outside the top 6 or 7 are doing anything of much interest. Be they from Plymouth or Paris, be it tippy tappy or hoofy smashy footballâ€¦ its all pretty much dross. The most important thing F365 Towers seems to not understand. Itâ€™s that English/British Managers are good craic. Allardyce, Redknapp, Warnock, Fergie, Bassettâ€¦ Theyâ€™re fun, theyâ€™re ridiculous, they are incredibly lacking in self-awareness. They make great TV. They will say funny things about their wives and curse on TV. Itâ€™s great. We should be encouraging the next lineage of this type of manager. Not frothing at the mouth anytime some lad from over the pond manages to get his team to string 3 passes together. So choose 4-4-2, choose 6 pints the night before the match, choose chat sh*t get banged, choose VINDALOO, choose idiotic interviews out the car window on transfer deadline day, choose losing the English job after a few weeks due to corruption, choose steak and kidney pies, choose saying â€œwe woz robbedâ€ after every defeat, choose blaming the ref, choose signing George Weahs cousin, choose hoofing the ball to the centre forwardâ€¦ (Born Slippy by Underworld fades inâ€¦)Shz  Graham Simons asked the Mailbox â€œWhere has all this hate for Everton come from?â€ One word answer â€“ Richarlison. Simples.Bladey Mick (Worst footballer everâ€¦.)  Arsenal relegatedPlenty of people I know would love Arsenal to get relegated, Graham â€“ they just arenâ€™t in a position it might happen. Shame really.Dan M  Who else has skills named after them? I told my wife Benzema scored a Panenka penalty. She looked at me like I was speaking in code. It got me thinking, other than the Cruyff turn, does anyone else have a skill or technique named after them? That Ronaldinho dummy trick, is that one? I know there are awards (Puskas) and even positions (Makelele), but for the life of me I canâ€™t think of skills. Iâ€™m sure I practised a McManaman turn in my school days, but might be making that up? Help!!Graeme, Glasgow

Content_title: Credit Lampard for â€˜rilingâ€™ Liverpool fans in, erm, 2-0 defeat
Contents: Well done Frank Lampard for â€˜rilingâ€™ Liverpool fans; only The Sun could be impressed with that. Just like Jose â€˜FOR 62 minutes, Frank Lampard pulled off his best Jose Mourinho impersonation and frustrated the hell out of Anfield.â€™ That would be a lovely opening line to Dave Kiddâ€™s Merseyside derby match report in The Sun if Jose Mourinho sides had not conceded in the 24th and 26th minutes of his last two (losing) trips to Anfield.  On the rilesWe are being a little facetious of course because Kidd was actually going all the way back to 2014 by referencing Chelseaâ€™s win at Anfield which derailed Liverpoolâ€™s title bid. And we are supposed to believe that Everton only losing 2-0 to Liverpool is worthy of that kind of comparisonâ€¦ â€˜Evertonâ€™s 68-year stay in the top flight may be in severe peril but Lampard and his team deserve some credit for riling Liverpoolâ€™s players, fans and fan-boy Sky pundit Jamie Carragher to the point of distraction.â€™ Yes, well done Frank. The one place where simply â€˜rilingâ€™ Liverpool is worthy of great praise is The Sun. â€˜There were obvious similarities with the infamous Demba Ba match in 2014, when Mourinhoâ€™s Chelsea side â€“ including Lampard and Mo Salah â€“ derailed Liverpoolâ€™s title bid with a 2-0 victory and a defensive masterclass.â€™ Chelsea were 1-0 up by half-time in that game so the â€˜obvious similaritiesâ€™ were put to bed pretty bloody early on. Oh and Operation No Blame Lampard is truly on hereâ€¦ â€˜Liverpool fans taunted their opponents by gleefully chanting the name of Rafa Benitez â€“ now even more cherished by the red half of the city, for having done such a fine job of propelling the blue half towards the Championship.â€™ He was sacked with Everton six points clear of the relegation zone, fella. We think Lampard might be a bit responsible. But also, well done for â€˜rilingâ€™ Liverpool as your team lost 2-0.  Vague-abondsâ€˜NOT FOR THE FAINT-HEARTED: Carragher pinpoints games where Liverpool and Man City could slip up in close run title raceâ€™ is the leading headline on the Mirror Sport headline. Except, well, he never says anything about the faint-hearted and never actually pin-points (â€˜find or identify with great accuracy or precisionâ€™)any games other than to say that â€œfor both teams, the game in-between a Champions League semi-final will take so much out of youâ€. But â€˜Carragher says playing loads of games is really hardâ€™ doth butter no parsnips/claim no easy clicks.  Poking holesâ€˜Liverpool star Fabinho pokes fun at Richarlison with cheeky social media post showing his beaten Everton rival clutching his face in pain after the pairâ€™s clash during feisty Merseyside derbyâ€™ is the headline (yes, thatâ€™s a headline not an opening paragraph) on MailOnline. This is the â€˜cheeky social media postâ€™ in question: What a win! Until the end, boys! ğŸ’ªğŸ¾ğŸ™ğŸ½ğŸ”´ pic.twitter.com/x7RfdeeEAL â€” Fabinho (@_fabinhotavares) April 24, 2022  How very â€˜cheekyâ€™ to include two pics featuring Fabinho himself, as he (or a member of his team) does after every single Liverpool game. He â€˜couldnâ€™t resist poking fun at Richarlison as he took to social media after the 2-0 victoryâ€™ apparently. Well he could resist. Because he did.  VAR from an explanationOver at the Liverpool Echo, they are more than happy to fan all of the flames with this click-tastic headline: â€˜Premier League confirm why VAR didnâ€™t give two decisions for Everton against Liverpoolâ€™ Oh this will be good. Though the Premier League commenting on VAR decisions is curious. But here we go, we have clickedâ€¦ â€˜The Premier League have confirmed why two controversial decisions went against Everton in their defeat to Liverpool on Sunday afternoon.â€™ Come on then. Letâ€™s hear itâ€¦ â€˜Frank Lampard particularly bemoaned an incidentin the second half of the game when Anthony Gordon was seemingly brought down inside the box by Joel Matip. Despite the wingerâ€™s appeals, Stuart Attwell decided against awarding a spot kick. â€˜Earlier on in the match, numerous supporters had also spotted incidents involving Sadio Mane shortly before half time. TheLiverpoolstar looked to raise his hand to the faces of both Allan and Mason Holgate, but escaped a red card.â€™ Yes, yes. Letâ€™s get to the part where the Premier League have confirmed something that theyâ€™re not actually in control ofâ€¦ â€˜The ECHO understands both incidents were checked by the VAR, although that wasnâ€™t clear from inside the stadium. On both occasions, it was deemed that there was not enough to intervene with the on-field decisions that were given.â€™ So no Premier League confirmation at all but rather a repeat of the EXACT SITUATION THAT OCCURS IN EVERY SINGLE PREMIER LEAGUE GAME. But we clicked so who are the f***ing idiots here?   Should we justâ€¦Elsewhere on the Liverpool Echo, they are following the Reach guidelines for confusing the hell out of people into clicking with one of those random quote headlines that seems to be all the rage in certain quarters. After years of picking out the best quotes for headlines, the current trend is to pick a couple of random, anodyne words to confound the readers into a click. Frankly, itâ€™s shit. â€Will haveâ€™ â€“ John Terry makes Anthony Gordon prediction after Everton performanceâ€™ â€˜Will haveâ€™? What sort of a quote is that? What John Terry actually said on Instagram: â€œI love watching this young man. Top player who will have a big career in the game. Gives everything for the shirt every week.â€ There are at least three better quotes to highlight than â€˜will haveâ€™ but thatâ€™s not the point here, is it? The point is to confuse you into clicking. Should we just headline this Mediawatch as â€˜should we justâ€™? Actually, thatâ€™s not a bad ideaâ€¦

Content_title: Jurgen Kloppâ€™s Liverpool contract: Great for the Premier League, bad for Premier League clubs
Contents: Jurgen Klopp has signed a new deal, Liverpool are buzzing and the Premier League is rubbing its hands together. The clubs in the Premier League sigh and prepare for four more years of domination and biannual (probably quadannual) drubbings. Kloppâ€™s new deal at Anfield takes him through to the summer of 2026. Itâ€™s brilliant news for Liverpool, obviously. The club love him, the fans love him, the players love him and the feeling goes both ways. Klopp is now synonymous with Liverpool Football Club; may God help the poor sod who will eventually replace him. But heâ€™s just as valuable a commodity to the Premier League. Klopp, as a manager, is â€˜worth the entrance fee aloneâ€™ â€“ worth spending half your wages on 27 different platforms to watch him fist-pumping at the Kop, grimacing like a gladiator removing their latest head, conducting those special Anfield nights. Heâ€™s the box office manager of a box office football team playing box office football. And the Premier League smiles, pats him on the cap and reaps the rewards. The English top flight is no longer The Best League In The World simply because English people said so often enough. It is now actually the best league in the world, owing to it having the best football teams. After a fallow period of five years without a representative in the Champions League final, should Manchester City and Liverpool hold onto their advantages in the semi-finals this season, seven of the last ten finalists will have hailed from this green and pleasant land. The news of Kloppâ€™s extension as good as guarantees further years of supremacy. Itâ€™s not just about Liverpool, but about the inability for those who wish to compete to rest on their laurels. The Premier League bar is as high as itâ€™s ever been, and given Liverpoolâ€™s brilliance on the pitch, where they swarm over and suffocate opponents to win game after game with no let up,and off it, where they have an extraordinary record of making perfect signings, the ceiling may not yet be in sight. Itâ€™s a harrowing thought for all Premier League clubs, including Manchester City, who are right there alongside them. The Premier League will want to bleed what has become a wonderful â€“ if slightly too respectful â€“ rivalry for the four years Klopp is now committed to, at the very least. That relies on Pep Guardiola. Both City and Liverpool are excellent football teams with very gifted footballers, but the reason either is able to keep pace with the other is down to their managers. Liverpool without Klopp would not be in this title race and the same goes for City without Guardiola.  The City boss is about to enter the final year of his contract at the Etihad and will have spent seven seasons at the club by the summer of 2023. He has extraordinary footballers at his disposal, at a football club with extraordinary resources to continue to develop and improve. But that alone may not be enough for him to extend his deal; heâ€™s been on the verge of leaving on more than one occasion and this is comfortably the longest heâ€™s stayed at one club. If anything was to persaude him to remain it may well be the promise of further great battles with his affable nemesis on Merseyside. Draining though that sounds to us mortals, these guys live for the stress of competition at the highest level, and there is, and will be, no higher level while these two masters continue to push each other. Itâ€™s terrible news for those playing catch up â€“ 2026 is a long way off.Mikel Arteta will be in the process of extending his â€˜processâ€™, Harry Kane will be 33 and still trophyless at Tottenham (or Manchester United), Chelsea will be firmly reduced to a cup team losing two finals a season, and Wayne Rooney will be overseeing the overhaul of the overhaul at Old Trafford. With one flick of his pen, Klopp has fail-safed Liverpoolâ€™s future,cemented the Premier Leagueâ€™s top spot in the European league hierarchy for the foreseeable, and f***ed all of us except Manchester City, who will be f***ing us further.

Content_title: Klopp doubts his new deal at Liverpool will be deciding factor for Salah, Mane futures
Contents: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp does not believe his new deal will be the deciding factor on whether the likes of Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane commit their long-term futures to the club. The pair, along with Roberto Firmino and midfielder Naby Keita, have contracts which expire next summer and negotiations have dragged on for some time. With Klopp now staying until 2026, there is a greater degree of security at the club but the German is not convinced that will make a huge difference to individual playersâ€™ decisions. Liverpool press to depress opponents as Klopp keeps complacency completely at bay â€œThat is more a question for the boys, what it exactly means for them but all fine, my relationship with them is great,â€ he said. â€œMy point is in life there are more important things to think about, not only who is the manager but knowing who the manager and coaching staff is is important thing because when you know what you have with other clubs where you could go, you donâ€™t know exactly. â€œThere is no 100 per cent in this business but I think it is pretty likely I will stay for a little bit longer because other coaches are there at other clubs. â€œIf it is a positive sign for the boys, great, but I donâ€™t think this will be the one decisive thing for whatever decision they want to make. â€œIt is their own life but we just wanted to guarantee that everyone who wants to be here knows what he can expect.â€ Salahâ€™s contract negotiations have dragged on for several months now, with the Egypt international stressing last week the delay was â€œnot about money at allâ€. However, whether the guarantee of working with Klopp for the final peak years of his career will be persuasive enough for him to accept an offer below a reported Â£400,000-plus a week remains to be seen. But whichever way that decision goes Klopp will not hold it against him or any other player who sees their future elsewhere. Asked whether players in the past had spoken to him about his own future before committing theirs, Klopp added: â€œThat happened as well. I donâ€™t judge loyalty because of these kind of things. â€œFrom my side yes, if I commit, I commit but I know a playerâ€™s career is 15 years and I have great relationships today with former players of mine who wanted to leave in specific moments when I thought â€˜Thatâ€™s a shame you go nowâ€™. â€œIf a player tells you early enough he wants to go then you have to deal with it: is there a club that wants him, is there a transfer fee? â€œIf a player is coming at the last moment and tells you on Sunday when the transfer window closes on the Monday â€˜By the way, I canâ€™t stay hereâ€™ then (itâ€™s) â€˜Sorry my friend, thatâ€™s not possibleâ€™. â€œTo plan we need decisions at a specific point and thatâ€™s what we are working on. â€œBut I donâ€™t judge people if they are loyal or not if they say during a contract â€˜I want to go somewhere else and see what the weather is like or how the grass is thereâ€™. â€œThatâ€™s not the case. I think you see loyalty in other areas.â€ Join us LIVE as the boss speaks to the media ahead of the trip to face Newcastle United tomorrow! ğŸ™#NEWLIV https://t.co/3lPLfIFvOn â€” Liverpool FC (@LFC) April 29, 2022 Klopp takes his side to Newcastle for the lunchtime kick-off on Saturday looking to put the pressure on Premier League leaders Manchester City, who are the late game at Leeds, by opening up a two-point gap at the top. With one foot in the Champions League final, holding a 2-0 lead over Villarreal ahead of a trip to Spain next week, and an FA Cup final against Chelsea in a fortnight, an unprecedented but unlikely quadruple remains on track. Klopp said him signing a new contract is the start of a new era at the club. â€œWe donâ€™t think about changing the team in the next two or three years or whatever, but you have to prepare the little things so that you are ready for the future as well,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s why I really think itâ€™s a really good place to be or a good place to join, if not the perfect place. â€œWe cannot wait 10 years. We have to do it now. Itâ€™s no threat. This is only the start, to be honest. Thatâ€™s the plan, that we really, really go for it. â€œThereâ€™s nothing guaranteed, itâ€™s why we have to enjoy the journey. The journey so far is a great one but we donâ€™t know if we will win anything.â€

Content_title: Big Weekend: Newcastle v Liverpool, Phillips against Man City, Arsenal, Lampard faces Chelsea
Contents: Itâ€™s another huge weekend at the top and bottom of the Premier League, with Liverpool facing their toughest remaining fixture while Frank Lampard takes on some familiar facesâ€¦ Game to watch â€“ Newcastle v Liverpool Liverpool start the Premier League weekend with probably their toughest assignment of the five left between now and the end of the season. Which is further testament to the job being done by Eddie Howe at Newcastle. This is a clash of the top-flightâ€™s two most in-form teams of 2022. Howeâ€™s Newcastle entered January second-from-bottom of the table, with all hopes pinned on the winter window as their only route out of danger. Of course, spending Â£92million helped but there is much more behind the Magpiesâ€™ stunning revival, with Howe at the core of it all. Since the turn of the year, Newcastle have earned six fewer points than Liverpool but two more than Manchester City. Only City have beaten the Toon on Tyneside since Howe took over and they are currently on a six-game winning streak at home, their best run since 2004, to take them to ninth in the table. So the prospect of going to a stirringly unified St Jamesâ€™ Park on Saturday lunchtime, in between Champions League semi-final legs, has to be the most daunting test Liverpool have remaining as they bid to chase down City at the summit. Tyneside is the only place that could currently give Anfield a run in the optimism stakes and Howe has harnessed that energy perfectly. Liverpool canâ€™t hope to quieten the crowd, but in their current form, you wouldnâ€™t bet against the Reds if they had half a million flag-waving Geordies inside St Jamesâ€™ Park on Saturday. Their biggest threat is a Newcastle side pulling for each other like few other teams at present with the licence and freedom to express themselves. Jurgen Klopp reckons the Reds are up against the schedulers too having tried and failed to get this game shifted from the lunchtime slot after a Wednesday night European game. Some rotation is inevitable but Klopp has a balancing act to perform with Newcastle energised and primed to expose any weariness or rustiness.  Cheeky Punt  Player to watch â€“ Kalvin Phillips If Liverpool come through their Tyneside trip unscathed, the pressure is heaped upon Manchester City to keep pace on Saturday evening when they cross the Pennines to visit Dirty Leeds. Jesse Marschâ€™s men may remain in a relegation fight but the Yorkshiremen are currently unbeaten in five games as they prepare to welcome a City side that has beaten them only once in three attempts since the start of last season. Admittedly, that was a 7-0 pummelling at the Etihad earlier this season, but Marsch has instilled some backbone into the side that was ravaged by injuries when they were embarrassed by the champions before Christmas. Part of that renewed resilience stems from Phillipsâ€™ return, with the England midfielder playing 90 minutes for Leeds on Monday night for the first time since November. Phillips helped Leeds earn consecutive clean sheets for the first time since his last full outing, also against Palace at Elland Road. At Selhurst Park, Marsch described Leeds defensively as being able to bend without breaking, and the aim will be the same against City on Saturday. Phillips is still, in his own words, getting up to speed with fitness and the demands of Marschâ€™s system, but the Manchester United target will be key to Leeds stopping the leaders, whatever form and shape they take while Pep Guardiola juggles their domestic duties with the Champions League semi-final second leg at Real Madrid in midweek.  Manager to watch â€“ Frank Lampard Lampard will be hoping City can do them a favour at Leeds and Watford can stop Burnleyâ€™s revival before the Everton boss comes up against his former side Chelsea on Sunday lunchtime, by which time they could be five points adrift of safety. The Everton manager has taken a kicking lately, especially so after the Merseyside derby, when the Toffees went to Anfield and highlighted their own inferiority to their neighbours. Such tactics were the act of a man made desperate by his teamâ€™s plight and while they were easier to explain away at Anfield, Goodison Park wonâ€™t accept a repeat of that approach on home soil against Thomas Tuchelâ€™s Blues. Evertonians, and the Premier League table, demand a home win, or at the very least the intent to claim one. Lampardâ€™s blueprint will likely resemble that which almost held Manchester City at Goodison when Everton were denied a stonewall penalty late on that could have boosted them and Liverpool in their respective fights at each end of the table. The Toffees have been considerably more resilient at home and Everton supporters are rallying with orchestrated shows of support before and during the visit of Chelsea. Lampard has to tap into that positivity and empower his side to attack a Chelsea side that has conceded 13 goals in seven games. Before two away games, one point might not be enough for the Toffees.  Team to watch â€“ Arsenal Tune in at 4:30pm on Sunday to see which Arsenal shows up for the London derby at West Hamâ€¦ Might it be the imperious Gunners who dominated Chelsea in their last capital clash; will we see again the nervous side which turned over Manchester United despite never looking comfortable; or could the team who lost three on the bounce to Brighton, Palace and Southampton show up to once again derail their top-four ambitions? Fortunately for Arsenal, Spurs are similarly as flaky; United are a mess; West Ham have other priorities and are focusing on a route to the Champions League via Europa League glory. The fact the Hammersâ€™ semi-final clashes with Eintracht Frankfurt sandwich this derby could also play into Mikel Artetaâ€™s hands when he takes the Gunners to the London Stadium. David Moyes made six changes last week at Chelsea and the Irons boss looks set to repeat his rotation this weekend, especially with four centre-backs potentially missing. Arsenal have somewhat ridden their luck to regain control of the race for fourth but the breaks wonâ€™t keep coming if they fluff their lines again this weekend. A convincing performance is optional but three points are compulsory.   EFL game to watch â€“QPR v Sheffield United The Bladesâ€™ trip to Loftus Road kicks off a frenetic penultimate round of Championship fixtures, with the eight clubs below Fulham all potential play-off contenders. United currently occupy sixth place â€“ the final play-off berth â€“ and need a win against Rangers, who have fallen way off the pace in the promotion race, to make the final-day meeting with champions-elect Fulham a little less daunting. You can watch Fulhamâ€™s attempt to sew up the title against fifth-placed Luton on Monday, with a fairly inconsequential meeting between Barnsley and Preston also televised on Saturday afternoon. For a full preview of the second-tier action, check out Benjamin Bloomâ€™s Champ Big Weekend.  European game to watch â€“ AC Milan v Fiorentina The title races in France and Germany have already been wrapped up while Real Madrid only need a point at home to Espanyol on Saturday afternoon to clinch the La Liga crown. So beyond these shores, itâ€™s off to Italy for the most exciting climaxâ€¦ Inter had the chance to go top on Wednesday evening when they played their game in hand against Bologna. But the Nerazzurri f***ed it in calamitous style, going down 2-1 like thisâ€¦ CATASTROPHIC! ğŸ˜² It's a nightmare for Inter Milan's second choice goalkeeper, IonuÈ› Radu. Could that cost them the Serie A title? pic.twitter.com/7NcXOxiMwZ â€” Football on BT Sport (@btsportfootball) April 27, 2022  So with four games remaining, Milan hold retain a two-point lead at the summit before they host Fiorentina on Sunday afternoon before Inter go to Udinese.

Content_title: TAA makes Liverpool title admission after Man City draw
Contents: Liverpool defender Trent Alexander-Arnold accepts they are relying on another team to produce a surprise against Manchester City and do them a favour in the title race. A thrilling 2-2 draw at the Etihad left the situation at the top of the Premier League unchanged with Pep Guardiolaâ€™s side leading by one point, with just seven games remaining. The run-in suggests City have the greater advantage as they face Brighton, Watford, Leeds and Newcastle â€“ all teams in the bottom half â€“ before facing Wolves, West Ham and then Aston Villa away on the final day of the season. 16 Conclusions: Manchester City 2-2 Liverpool Liverpool, by comparison, have to play top-seven sides Manchester United and Tottenham as well as Merseyside rivals Everton, while also having to tackle Villa, Wolves, Newcastle and Southampton. â€œWe want to win every game weâ€™re in, no matter the opposition we come up against,â€ the defender told beIN Sports. â€œIt says a lot about us that weâ€™ve got that slight disappointment not to come here (to City) and win. â€œIt was very important for us not to lose this game, weâ€™re still in a decent position but it is in their hands. â€œA few years ago (in 2018-19 when they were pipped to the title by a single point) this is what happened. They (City) went on a really good run and we werenâ€™t able to capitalise on that. Hopefully, this time around, they will drop a few points for us. â€œEvery week there is a surprising result in the Premier League. Weâ€™re just hoping we are not on the end of one and City are. â€œIt is seven games. Who knows what will happen, hopefully we make it exciting. It might go down to the last day again.â€ 44 â€“ Since the start of 2018-19, Trent Alexander-Arnold has assisted more Premier League goals than any other player (44). His assist for Diogo Jota today means he has now set up at least one goal against all other 19 current Premier League sides. Unstoppable. pic.twitter.com/kiVtJFUJQz â€” OptaJoe (@OptaJoe) April 10, 2022  On Saturday the two teams face each other again but this time in a make-or-break FA Cup semi-final at Wembley. Manager Jurgen Klopp believes their experience at the Etihad will help somewhat in planning for that game, although he expects another high-intensity, absorbing encounter. But his immediate focus has to be on Wednesdayâ€™s Champions League quarter-final second leg at home to Benfica, over whom they hold a 3-1 advantage. â€œWould I loved to have won the game? Yeah. Would it have changed our situation? Not really, not now,â€ Klopp told BBC Sport after his side failed to get the win which would have lifted them above City into top spot. â€œIâ€™m already in the Benfica mood but we will use this game and try to understand. We will see what they do next time, what we will do next time. â€œThe main problem for the (semi-final) game is extra time â€“ you canâ€™t see for 120 minutes this kind of football. Thank God we can use five substitutes.â€

Content_title: Cole hails Liverpool star as â€˜better passer and crosserâ€™ than Beckham
Contents: Joe Cole thinks Liverpool defender Trent Alexander-Arnold is a â€œbetter passer and crosserâ€ than Manchester United legend David Beckham. The England international has emerged as one of the best passers in world football in recent years at Anfield. Alexander-Arnold has got 43 assists Premier League assists over the last four seasons and has become one of the most important attacking players at Liverpool. Gossip: Liverpool eye Bayern slayer; Ten Hag wants Neves at Man Utd The Liverpool wing-back was brilliant again as the Reds beat Benfica 3-1 in the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final, showing off his range of passing. And former Chelsea and Liverpool midfielder Cole likened him to Man Utd and England legend Beckham but thinks he is actually â€œbetterâ€ in many ways. â€œLook, it doesnâ€™t need words. Itâ€™s Beckham-like but I think heâ€™s actually a better passer than Beckham, a better crosser than Beckham,â€ Cole toldBT Sport. â€œThatâ€™s saying something because Becks was the best of my generation. The problem England have got is weâ€™ve also got [Chelsea right-back] Reece James. â€œYou cannot leave either of them out, theyâ€™ve both got outstanding attributes. Tactically, can Gareth Southgate find a way of getting them both in the team?â€ â€œI think heâ€™s actually a better passer and crosser than Beckhamâ€ When it comes to ball delivery, there arenâ€™t many players in the world right now better than Trent Alexander-Arnold according to @rioferdy5 & Joe Cole â˜„ï¸#UCLTONIGHT pic.twitter.com/QAd4zl8sf1 â€” Football on BT Sport (@btsportfootball) April 6, 2022 Fellow BT Sport pundit Rio Ferdinand added: : â€œTrent is as good a passer as anyone on the planet right now, I donâ€™t care. â€œWhen I saw one of his passes yesterday, I was screaming. And itâ€™s not usually passes that do that to me. Itâ€™s out or order the way he passes the ball. Itâ€™s not only the execution, itâ€™s the vision.â€ Meanwhile, Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp has played down suggestions that their crunch clash with Manchester City is a Premier League title decider. â€œIf we win against City, which is already difficult enough, I think no one would think, â€˜thatâ€™s it, decidedâ€™, because of the quality of the opponent,â€ said Klopp. â€œWe play now against the best team in the world but we will give it a try anyway. â€œEveryone knows about the importance of the next game, but after this game there will be other game in another competition but also in the Premier League as well. â€œIf you cannot be first you want to be second, if you are behind then you want to come closer, if you are close you want to overtake. â€œThatâ€™s the situation and we will give it a proper try.â€

Content_title: Two Serie A clubs â€˜leading the chase to landâ€™ Man Utd midfielder amid interest from Newcastle

The two Serie A clubs have â€˜registered their interestâ€™ in him but it is noted that â€˜there is competition from clubs in the Premier League and abroad.â€™ Ralf Rangnick thinks Man Utd could need as many as three new strikers in the summer transfer window with the interim boss refusing to answer a question on Cristiano Ronaldoâ€™s future. When asked if Ronaldo would fit into Erik ten Hagâ€™s plans, Rangnick told Sky Sports: â€œThis is a question you need to ask Erik ten Hag. â€œHeâ€™s showed that he can still be a vital part of this team, but itâ€™s obvious the team needs some more strikers. There should be two or three new strikers next season, itâ€™s pretty obvious.â€ On summer recruitment, he added: â€œIf you think of Manchester City and Liverpool, they brought in [players] every transfer window. â€œThey strengthened the team, they brought in players not that popular at the time when they signed and developed into the two best teams in the world. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be surprised if they play in the Champions League final in a few weeks. â€œThis shows it is possible that this can happen and it would not necessarily need three, four years in order to do that.â€

Content_title: Man Utdâ€™s five midfield targets: the cases for and against
Contents: Manchester Unitedâ€™s priority for the summer transfer window is said to be a central midfielder. But which one? Here are some of the arguments for and against five of the most often linked targetsâ€¦ Declan Rice For The England international has proved himself to be just the man United need to anchor their midfield. Rice initially carved out a reputation as a screener and this season has shown his credentials as a box-to-boxer. Rice has made more interceptions than anyone in the top flight and only Brentfordâ€™s Christian Norgaard has made more combined tackles and interceptions than the 23-year-oldâ€™s total of 147. There seems very little risk with Rice. United know exactly what they would be getting and that certainty usually comes at a premium. About thatâ€¦ Against United will have to break their transfer record and almost certainly the Premier Leagueâ€™s for most expensive signing if they want to get Rice out of West Ham. The player would almost certainly like to take the next step (assuming itâ€™s not a lateral move between West Ham and United come the end of the season) and the Irons, under no pressure to offload with Rice under contract until 2025, could sell a huge deal to their fanbase. But that would require United to cough up in excess of Â£100million. Would they do that, especially if they arenâ€™t in the Champions League next season? United might find themselves shopping with a tighter budget.   Kalvin Phillips For If United canâ€™t get Rice, perhaps they might opt for his mate in Englandâ€™s midfield. Phillipsâ€™ quality has been emphasised by how badly heâ€™s been missed by Leeds during his recent injury-enforced absence. Heâ€™s not the only player Marcelo Bielsa and Jesse Marsch have been without, but Phillips seems like the biggest miss, especially given the way opponents have played through the Leeds midfield when heâ€™s not manning the engine room. Even if Leeds appear to be on a firmer footing in the Premier League after two dramatic wins last week, the Whitesâ€™ finances could make them susceptible to offers on Phillips. Reports suggest he could go for Â£60million, which may be around half the price of Rice. Against A few clubs are said to be keen on Phillips, with Liverpool, Man City, Newcastle and Aston Villa all credited with an interest. Indeed, Villa are reported to be leading the race. If Phillips is ushered towards the door by Leeds while his hometown club seeks a windfall, then the 26-year-old will have to consider very carefully his next move if he wants to protect a legacy heâ€™s cultivated at Elland Road as one of their own. Crossing the Pennines would tarnish that. Alan Smith made that move when Leeds were on the bones of their arse and they still havenâ€™t really forgiven him in West Yorkshire. Indeed, it was reported last year that Phillips has already decided not to risk it. So United might be wise not to chase a lost cause. Of all those reportedly interested in Phillips this summer, I am told West Ham and Aston Villa are the only clubs to make enquiries so far. WHUFC remain interested following their January offers and AVFC CEO Purslow is a longtime admirer of Kalvin. As of now, no contact from MUFC â€” Jonathan Shrager (@JonathanShrager) March 22, 2022   Ryan Gravenberch For Gravenberch remains a teenager but has already amassed almost 100 appearances for Ajax and 10 caps for Holland. By the end of the season, he will have played almost four full senior campaigns before his 20th birthday. According to his former youth coach with the Amsterdam club, the deep-lying midfielder is â€œa better version of Paul Pogbaâ€ with the physique of Frank Rijkaard. Gravenberchâ€™s career so far has been spent under the wing of Erik ten Hag. If United opt to name the Ajax coach as their new manager, then there would be sense in having him bring a player he knows better than anyone else can claim to. He would be half the price of Phillips and around a quarter of the cost Rice might be, which is important now. Against Unitedâ€™s last move for an Ajax midfielder was hardly a roaring success. Perhaps that is why Gravenberch is said to be lukewarm about the prospect of moving to Old Trafford, especially with Bayern Munich keen. Apparently, Gravenberch would prefer to hear first what the Bavarians have to say and the story goes that personal terms have already been agreed. All Bayern must do is find common ground with Ajax over a fee and their opening offer of Â£21million wasnâ€™t too far from achieving its purpose. United may well be wasting their time putting Gravenberch at the top of their list of targets if he really is edging closer to Bayern. Where would you rather go right now?  Amadou Haidara For Ralf Rangnick certainly thought United would suit Haidara since he recommended that the club move on the Mali international in January. They decided not to because, well, United. The interim manager knows Haidara well from his time at RB Leipzig. It was Rangnick who took him to Germany from Salzburg and Haidara established himself as an important player for Julian Nagelsmann, Marsch and now Domenico Tedesco. Haidara can screen but Rangnick wanted him because of his ability to press further up the pitch. We assume Unitedâ€™s new coach will want to play a similar style to that which Rangnick has struggled to implement with the current squad and Haidara would certainly improve those prospects. In contrast to Gravenberch and Phillips, the prospect of playing for United arouses Haidara. â€œMy dream club is Manchester United,â€ he said in 2019. Though plenty has happened since which may have prompted a rethink. Against Rangnickâ€™s opinion presumably hasnâ€™t been founded on Haidaraâ€™s stats. In the Bundesliga alone: 109 players have attempted more tackles; 195 have a higher tackle success rate than Haidaraâ€™s 22.6 per cent; 113 players have applied more pressures; and 27 have a higher pressure success rate. For comparison, Scott McTominayâ€™s tackle success percentage is 49.2 per cent and Fredâ€™s is 25.4 per cent, which is the worst in the United squad, but still better than Haidaraâ€™s.  Aurelien Tchouameni For United are just one of the clubs interested in Tchouameni. Apparently, so too are Chelsea, City and Liverpool. Plus other big hitters on the continent. But the 22-year-old reportedly has the Premier League in mind for when he leaves Monaco. Tchouameni was Ligue 1â€™s best young player last season and already has seven France caps to his name. So impressive has he been while standing in for Nâ€™Golo Kante, Pogba said: â€œWe wish him to play a lot more games and that I am always by his side.â€ There is almost no chance of the pair teaming up at Old Trafford, butTchouameni could pick up a lot quicker the instructions of a new manager than Pogba and his team-mates have shown they are able or willing to over the years. â€œIn his position, you need to be disciplined and organise others around you,â€ said then-Monaco coach Niko Kovac. â€œHe is always trying to learn and understand. He absorbs all the information we give to him.â€ Tchouameni wouldnâ€™t break the bank for United, with a reported asking price of Â£42million within the Red Devilsâ€™ budget this summer, even if they are tightening their belts. Against Technically and tactically, there is no reason United shouldnâ€™t go forTchouameni this summer. Heâ€™s within budget, young but gathering experience quick and only getting better. But, of course, United are not the only club keen on the 22-year-old. Given how United hate losing face, will they really be prepared to go up against the likes of City and Liverpool when their rivals can offer Champions League football when they most likely cannot? Thatâ€™s not to say they shouldnâ€™t move decisively overTchouameni â€“ just donâ€™t expect them to.

Content_title: Tuchel tells Chelsea to beat Man Utd to â‚¬80m star â€˜at all costsâ€™
Contents: Thomas Tuchel has urged Chelsea to beat Manchester United to the signing ofAurelien Tchouameni â€˜at all costsâ€™. Tchouameni has emerged as one of the finest young talents in European football in the last year, starring for Monaco and the France international team. READ MORE: 2020 vision: Every PL clubâ€™s best signing of the decade so far Paul Pogba played alongsideTchouameni in Franceâ€™s 2-1 win over Spain in the Nations League final in October, and hailed his â€œextraordinaryâ€ talent. Pogba said:â€œVery, very good. Heâ€™s not a boy, heâ€™s a man. â€œItâ€™s a pleasure to play next to him. He brings a lot of energy. A lot of energy, extraordinary technical and physical quality. â€œWe wish him to play a lot more games and that I am always by his side.â€ Despite Chelseaâ€™s strength in the two holding midfield roles, they have struggled with absnences in those positions this season, and with Nâ€™Golo Kante and Jorginho both now 30 years old, Tuchel wants fresh blood in the middle of the park. Conor Gallagher is expected to return from his loan at Crystal Palace to stake a claim for a place in the Chelsea team next season, but his form hasnâ€™t lessened their interest in Tchouameni. The 21-year-old â€“ valued by Monaco at â‚¬80million â€“ is also on Unitedâ€™s radar, with some reports suggesting the Red Devils are leading the race. But Marca (via football.london) claim Tuchel has singled outTchouameni as his number one target and heâ€™s told Chelsea to land him â€˜at all costsâ€™ this summer. In an interview with Lâ€™Equipe, Tchouameni has previously discussed his future, insisting that he does not let it distract him from his work with Monaco. â€œI remember I was in Paris, after the Nations League. I woke up and my phone had blown up,â€ he said. â€œMy father called me, we talked about everything and he told me that I was on the front page of Marca. Content_title: Man Utdâ€™s five midfield targets: the cases for and against
Contents: Manchester Unitedâ€™s priority for the summer transfer window is said to be a central midfielder. But which one? Here are some of the arguments for and against five of the most often linked targetsâ€¦ Declan Rice For The England international has proved himself to be just the man United need to anchor their midfield. Rice initially carved out a reputation as a screener and this season has shown his credentials as a box-to-boxer. Rice has made more interceptions than anyone in the top flight and only Brentfordâ€™s Christian Norgaard has made more combined tackles and interceptions than the 23-year-oldâ€™s total of 147. There seems very little risk with Rice. United know exactly what they would be getting and that certainty usually comes at a premium. About thatâ€¦ Against United will have to break their transfer record and almost certainly the Premier Leagueâ€™s for most expensive signing if they want to get Rice out of West Ham. The player would almost certainly like to take the next step (assuming itâ€™s not a lateral move between West Ham and United come the end of the season) and the Irons, under no pressure to offload with Rice under contract until 2025, could sell a huge deal to their fanbase. But that would require United to cough up in excess of Â£100million. Would they do that, especially if they arenâ€™t in the Champions League next season? United might find themselves shopping with a tighter budget.   Kalvin Phillips For If United canâ€™t get Rice, perhaps they might opt for his mate in Englandâ€™s midfield. Phillipsâ€™ quality has been emphasised by how badly heâ€™s been missed by Leeds during his recent injury-enforced absence. Heâ€™s not the only player Marcelo Bielsa and Jesse Marsch have been without, but Phillips seems like the biggest miss, especially given the way opponents have played through the Leeds midfield when heâ€™s not manning the engine room. Even if Leeds appear to be on a firmer footing in the Premier League after two dramatic wins last week, the Whitesâ€™ finances could make them susceptible to offers on Phillips. Reports suggest he could go for Â£60million, which may be around half the price of Rice. Against A few clubs are said to be keen on Phillips, with Liverpool, Man City, Newcastle and Aston Villa all credited with an interest. Indeed, Villa are reported to be leading the race. If Phillips is ushered towards the door by Leeds while his hometown club seeks a windfall, then the 26-year-old will have to consider very carefully his next move if he wants to protect a legacy heâ€™s cultivated at Elland Road as one of their own. Crossing the Pennines would tarnish that. Alan Smith made that move when Leeds were on the bones of their arse and they still havenâ€™t really forgiven him in West Yorkshire. Indeed, it was reported last year that Phillips has already decided not to risk it. So United might be wise not to chase a lost cause. Of all those reportedly interested in Phillips this summer, I am told West Ham and Aston Villa are the only clubs to make enquiries so far. WHUFC remain interested following their January offers and AVFC CEO Purslow is a longtime admirer of Kalvin. As of now, no contact from MUFC â€” Jonathan Shrager (@JonathanShrager) March 22, 2022   Ryan Gravenberch For Gravenberch remains a teenager but has already amassed almost 100 appearances for Ajax and 10 caps for Holland. By the end of the season, he will have played almost four full senior campaigns before his 20th birthday. According to his former youth coach with the Amsterdam club, the deep-lying midfielder is â€œa better version of Paul Pogbaâ€ with the physique of Frank Rijkaard. Gravenberchâ€™s career so far has been spent under the wing of Erik ten Hag. If United opt to name the Ajax coach as their new manager, then there would be sense in having him bring a player he knows better than anyone else can claim to. He would be half the price of Phillips and around a quarter of the cost Rice might be, which is important now. Against Unitedâ€™s last move for an Ajax midfielder was hardly a roaring success. Perhaps that is why Gravenberch is said to be lukewarm about the prospect of moving to Old Trafford, especially with Bayern Munich keen. Apparently, Gravenberch would prefer to hear first what the Bavarians have to say and the story goes that personal terms have already been agreed. All Bayern must do is find common ground with Ajax over a fee and their opening offer of Â£21million wasnâ€™t too far from achieving its purpose. United may well be wasting their time putting Gravenberch at the top of their list of targets if he really is edging closer to Bayern. Where would you rather go right now?  Amadou Haidara For Ralf Rangnick certainly thought United would suit Haidara since he recommended that the club move on the Mali international in January. They decided not to because, well, United. The interim manager knows Haidara well from his time at RB Leipzig. It was Rangnick who took him to Germany from Salzburg and Haidara established himself as an important player for Julian Nagelsmann, Marsch and now Domenico Tedesco. Haidara can screen but Rangnick wanted him because of his ability to press further up the pitch. We assume Unitedâ€™s new coach will want to play a similar style to that which Rangnick has struggled to implement with the current squad and Haidara would certainly improve those prospects. In contrast to Gravenberch and Phillips, the prospect of playing for United arouses Haidara. â€œMy dream club is Manchester United,â€ he said in 2019. Though plenty has happened since which may have prompted a rethink. Against Rangnickâ€™s opinion presumably hasnâ€™t been founded on Haidaraâ€™s stats. In the Bundesliga alone: 109 players have attempted more tackles; 195 have a higher tackle success rate than Haidaraâ€™s 22.6 per cent; 113 players have applied more pressures; and 27 have a higher pressure success rate. For comparison, Scott McTominayâ€™s tackle success percentage is 49.2 per cent and Fredâ€™s is 25.4 per cent, which is the worst in the United squad, but still better than Haidaraâ€™s.  Aurelien Tchouameni For United are just one of the clubs interested in Tchouameni. Apparently, so too are Chelsea, City and Liverpool. Plus other big hitters on the continent. But the 22-year-old reportedly has the Premier League in mind for when he leaves Monaco. Tchouameni was Ligue 1â€™s best young player last season and already has seven France caps to his name. So impressive has he been while standing in for Nâ€™Golo Kante, Pogba said: â€œWe wish him to play a lot more games and that I am always by his side.â€ There is almost no chance of the pair teaming up at Old Trafford, butTchouameni could pick up a lot quicker the instructions of a new manager than Pogba and his team-mates have shown they are able or willing to over the years. â€œIn his position, you need to be disciplined and organise others around you,â€ said then-Monaco coach Niko Kovac. â€œHe is always trying to learn and understand. He absorbs all the information we give to him.â€ Tchouameni wouldnâ€™t break the bank for United, with a reported asking price of Â£42million within the Red Devilsâ€™ budget this summer, even if they are tightening their belts. Against Technically and tactically, there is no reason United shouldnâ€™t go forTchouameni this summer. Heâ€™s within budget, young but gathering experience quick and only getting better. But, of course, United are not the only club keen on the 22-year-old. Given how United hate losing face, will they really be prepared to go up against the likes of City and Liverpool when their rivals can offer Champions League football when they most likely cannot? Thatâ€™s not to say they shouldnâ€™t move decisively overTchouameni â€“ just donâ€™t expect them to.

Content_title: Revealed: The shocking truth behind those Ferdinand quotes about Liverpool midfielder Thiago
Contents: Pep Guardiolaâ€™s future is a point of concern after a Champions League thriller, but those Rio Ferdinand quotes on Thiago are the big news. Increasingly stranger things Ian Ladyman of the Daily Mail understandably enjoyed himself at the Etihad but something was eating him up inside: â€˜We are four years in to the second decade of Middle East ownership now and watching this incredible game of European football it was hard not to wonder what further fabulous dramas may lie ahead. â€˜More particularly, it seemed increasingly strange â€“ as City traded thunderous blows with the best team in Spain â€“ to ponder why Pep Guardiola would even think about leaving when his current contract expires at the end of next season.â€™ That does seem an â€˜increasingly strangeâ€™ angle to â€˜ponderâ€™ after â€˜watching this incredible game of European footballâ€™, which is presumably why literally no-one else did. But here we are. Guardiola has a contract that runs until 2023. He has been at Manchester City since 2016. This is already his longest unbroken spell as manager of one club by two years. That tenure, a four-year reign at Barcelona, came to an end because of a self-confessed need to â€œrecharge my batteriesâ€. It is not difficult to figure out why Guardiola might leave when his deal expires. But again, why is this hypothetical scenario that might come to pass in 13 monthsâ€™ timeeven a subject of discussion after the first leg of an enthralling Champions League semi-final? There is no answer. Only more instances of things seeming strange. â€˜This is the City team that Guardiola built and much as they were brilliantly expansive and precocious here, it is one that will only grow better, wiser and more talented from this point. â€˜Next season, for example, the Premier League leaders are expected to have the Norwegian forward Erling Haaland in their ranks. â€˜So, yes, it seems strange that Guardiola would even think about leaving as he has previously suggested he will.â€™ It would be strange if Guardiola didnâ€™t think about leaving when his current contract of employment runs out. It would be strange if Guardiola was even looking beyond May, considering this season could yet end with Manchester City winning no trophies or claiming a Premier and Champions League double. It is downright bizarre that this is such a point of focus. â€˜For all its quirks, this has the look of the greatest City team Guardiola has assembled in his six years in England. Its rivalry with Liverpool is magnetic. â€˜If Guardiola does not continue to work here beyond next season, itâ€™s hard to wonder where he will go. Even harder to work out why.â€™ It truly is impossible to predict what a man who took a sabbatical after four years of intense and uninterrupted elite coaching could potentially do after seven years of intense and uninterrupted elite coaching. Hopefully by the end of that seventh year, Ladyman has figured out the â€˜increasingly strangeâ€™ world of football contracts.  Pep talk â€˜Pep Guardiola must be furious with narrow Man City win â€“ Real Madrid are comeback kingsâ€™ â€“ the Daily Mirror headline to John Crossâ€™ opinion piece. â€˜Pep Guardiolaâ€™s delight with Manchester Cityâ€™s swashbuckling win against Real Madrid outweighed any frustration about their inability to put the Champions League semi-final to bed in a jaw-dropping first legâ€™ â€“ MailOnline.  Spill the Thi The biggest story on Wednesday, of course, is not Manchester City beating Real Madrid 4-3 in a thriller. Itâ€™s that Rio Ferdinand has said some words about Thiago Alcantara. â€˜Rio Ferdinand claims Thiago Alcantara told him he wanted to sign for Man United before joining Liverpool from Bayern Munich and says his â€˜ridiculousâ€™ form shows â€˜players need timeâ€™â€¦ as he tips Jadon Sancho to emulate him,â€™ is the beefyMailOnline headline. They add with no little specificity that â€˜Ferdinand reveals the player told him he was keen on becoming a Red Devil in 2020 when he was linked with a move away from the Bundesligaâ€™. Except Ferdinand revealed no such thing. He was asked about Manchester Unitedâ€™s previous interest in the midfielder, said that he â€œspoke to himâ€ and Thiago â€œwanted to come to Unitedâ€. But this was in 2013. Not 2020, and definitely not â€˜before joining Liverpool from Bayern Munichâ€™. Ferdinand has even spoken about this at length before on this very same podcast. Still, if one outlet blinks then others must follow: â€˜Rio Ferdinand claims Thiago Alcantara â€œwantedâ€ to join Man Utd before Liverpool transferâ€™ â€“ Daily Mirror website. â€I spoke to himâ€™ â€“ Rio Ferdinand makes Thiago transfer claim over Liverpool and Man Unitedâ€™ â€“ Liverpool Echo, who echo the demonstrably erroneous claim that â€˜the former England international has claimedThiagotold him he was keen on a move to Old Trafford in 2020â€™. â€˜Rio Ferdinand claims Thiago Alcantara told him he wanted to make Man Utd transfer before moving to rivals Liverpoolâ€™ â€“ The Sun website, who even quote Ferdinand as saying â€œI spoke to him at the time he joinedâ€ Liverpool to make it sound more current, when he said no such thing.  But credit where itâ€™s due: Manchester Evening News say â€˜Rio Ferdinand makes Thiago admission over Manchester United â€˜interestâ€™, yet they clarify that he is talking about a situation many years ago, instead of following everyone else in pretending Thiago rejected Manchester United in favour of Liverpool. Actual fair play.  Saint Etienne â€œAnfield is hell!â€ â€“ Villarrealâ€™s Etienne Capoue claims Liverpool have worst stadiumâ€™ â€¦to play at as a visiting team, as the Daily Mirror website well knows.  Trophy strife The Liverpool Echo headline: â€˜Liverpool trophy priority is clear as one cup stands out in quadruple questâ€™ The Liverpool Echo sub-headline: â€˜All Liverpool fans will want the quadruple from here if possible â€“ but is there one trophy that means more than the others?â€™ You would hope so, considering Liverpoolâ€™s â€˜trophy priority is clear as one cup stands out in quadruple questâ€™. Yet of the two writers tasked with debating the point, Sean Bradbury argues the case for the Premier League and Richard Garnett is in favour of the Champions League.
