Thatâ€™s the nature of modern life and if it doesnâ€™t look bright and beautiful to you, youâ€™re just not drinking enough of the elite kool-aid. There are the elite clubs at the top and then the rest of us living off the fumes from their p*ss. Weâ€™ve been told it is the natural order of things for so long that it has become the natural order of things. After all, we keep electing elite people who keep kicking us in the face in the hope that this time itâ€™ll be someone we hate who gets kicked in the face, not us, even though those we think we hate have been sold to us as hate figures by the elite as a deliberate part of a divide and rule policy. The prevailing culture suggests that hanging onto quaint concepts such as club history and club culture and civic pride are for the slow witted and the old fashioned. Get with the programme. This is the world we voted for, this is the world we made happen with our choices, so stop resisting the inevitable. We couldâ€™ve made a different world but we didnâ€™t. Weâ€™ve doffed our caps and tugged our forelocks for so long now that we know no other way. The elite gets what they want, thatâ€™s how it works, so shut up and let the elite clubs have what they want. Weâ€™re not going to protest, not really, we never do. We make excuses, we lie to ourselves, we tell each other how loyal we are, how badly done to we are, but then we carry on as normal, shovelling money and power into the hands of the same elite, the same clubs and the wheel keeps turning. No-one â€˜saved the Premier Leagueâ€™ as the Chelsea fanâ€™s banner had it, we just got confused about our role in this psychodrama. So donâ€™t just wait for it to happen, letâ€™s call for the start of the ESL now, not to do so is against modernity, is against elitism, is against the very nature of life in 2022. What are we holding out for? We should be embracing this brave new world, telling them to get on with it and quickly, not hanging on to the old one out of nostalgia or out of belief in some sort of alternative narrative which imagines the elite will stop being the elite. Because maybe, just maybe, when we have put the elite clubs behind the velvet rope in the VIP lounge, we can get on making something much, much better without them.

Content_title: Atletico could face UEFA action over ugly scenes in Man City clash
Contents: Atletico Madrid could face UEFA action over the ugly scenes that occurred in their Champions League quarter-final with Manchester City on Wednesday. Scuffles broke out late in the match and in the tunnel as Atleticoâ€™s frustrations at their failure to prise open Cityâ€™s defence boiled over. Man City â€˜cool headsâ€™? They lost it against Atleticoâ€¦ UEFA could appoint an ethics and disciplinary inspector to fully investigate what happened, and will await and assess reports on the trouble from the referee and match delegate. City, protecting a 1-0 lead from last weekâ€™s first leg, withstood a barrage of pressure, intense provocation from a fired-up Atletico and a hostile atmosphere to reach the semi-finals after a hard-fought goalless draw. The first major flashpoint came late in the game as a melee erupted after Felipe kicked Cityâ€™s Phil Foden, whose head he had also bloodied in a poor earlier challenge. Amongst the trouble Atletico defender Stefan Savic pulled unused City substitute Jack Grealishâ€™s hair after the pair had exchanged words. Felipe was sent off for his involvement. Everybody needs a teammate who has your back like Oleksandr Zinchenko ğŸ˜¤#UCL pic.twitter.com/kbtFseC2d2 â€” Football on BT Sport (@btsportfootball) April 13, 2022 The problems continued after the teams left the field with players needing to be separated in the tunnel. TV footage showed objects being thrown and police reportedly became involved to restore order. There were also suggestions City manager Pep Guardiola had liquid thrown at him as he headed towards the tunnel. Guardiola later said he had â€œnothing to sayâ€ in relation to the trouble but did add that â€œeveryone saw the actionâ€. Guardiola preferred to focus on his sideâ€™s rearguard action in the face of ferocious pressure. City did hit the post through Ilkay Gundogan in the first half but spent most of the second period in a rearguard action as Atletico, criticised for their defensive attitude in the first leg, finally upped the tempo. â€œWe defended everything but they had the chances,â€ said Guardiola. â€œThey did everything. They know this competition and this stadium with their people. Always it is difficult. â€œThat is why it is a big compliment to the players because we have to live these kind of situations. We cannot expect every time, especially in the Champions League with the champions from Spain, we are going to make everything marvellous. â€œYou have to suffer. In part we suffered because we forgot to play but in part we suffered because the opponent was really good.  â€œWhen this happens you try to take the ball but you are not able. With the people and chances they had we had no chances to score a goal.â€ Victory in the bruising tie could also have come at a cost. As well as Foden needing to play with a bandaged head, Kevin De Bruyne and Kyle Walker were both taken off after knocks. City, who are chasing a treble this season, are back in action against Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-finals on Saturday. â€œWe are in big trouble,â€ Guardiola said on BT Sport. â€œWe cannot forget we played three days ago a tough game against Liverpool. We came here, we have a lot of injuries. â€œI donâ€™t know what will happen in the next weeks but today we are going to celebrate.â€ Action by UEFA would come just days after Atletico were hit with a partial stadium closure for the second leg against City for the â€œdiscriminatory behaviourâ€ of their fans during the game in Manchester last week. That punishment was suspended just hours before the match on Wednesday following an appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

Content_title: Arsenal â€˜encounter problemâ€™ in striker search following playerâ€™s â€˜nightmareâ€™
Contents: According to reports, Arsenal have â€˜encountered a problemâ€™ in their efforts to sign former Chelsea striker Alvaro Morata from Atletico Madrid. The Gunners will be in the market for a new striker this summer. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang departed the club in February to join Barcelona. Eddie Nketiah and Alexandre Lacazette may also leave as both are out of contract this summer. Earlier this week, the latter admitted that he was missing Champions League football. Have Arsenal turned this into a race for two CL places? Morata previously had an unsuccessful spell at Chelsea. He is now contracted to Atletico Madrid but he has been on loan at Juventus since 2020. The 29-year-old has netted eleven goals from his 42 appearances for the Serie A giants this season. Mundo Deportivo (via Sport Witness) are reporting that Morata is one of the attackers Arsenal are looking at. It is also suggested that Atletico Madrid would â€˜preferâ€™ their player to join the Gunners. It is being reported though that Arsenal have â€˜encountered a problemâ€™ in their attempts to bring in Morata. This is as the player had a â€˜really hard timeâ€™ at Chelsea. Itâ€™s even said that his spell at the Blues was â€˜little short of a nightmareâ€™. Morata is therefore cautious about returning to the Premier League, so this is a â€˜barrierâ€™ Arsenal and Atletico will have to move past. Elsewhere,Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta has admitted he has been unfair on striker Eddie Nketiah this season. The 22-year-old is out-of-contract at the Emirates this summer and looks set to depart for more regular game time. Arsenal are likely to bring in a new first-choice centre-forward this summer after allowing Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang to leave in January and Nketiah and Lacazette set to follow soon. Where Nketiah will be next season remains to be seen, although a number of Premier League clubs have reportedly shown interest in the forward. Speaking after the win over Chelsea, Arsenal boss Arteta admitted he should have played the forward more this season. Speaking to the BBC, the Spaniard said: â€œWhat Eddie has done tonight is because of what he has done for the last 10 months and no-one has noticed.â€ â€œI said to him I havenâ€™t been fair. I should have been playing him more. We have other issues as well and that has not been easy. But he deserved completely what happened to him tonight.â€ â€œWhen you look at him in training and how humble and hungry he is, good things happen to good people. If Iâ€™m happy for anyone it is especially him because I know what he has been through,â€ Arteta told Sky Sports. â€œThe same with [Mohamed] Elneny and Rob Holding. That is why we won the game today. I love the spirit of these players. When you lose matches you get criticised but for these players it is worth it. They are really growing.â€

Content_title: Atletico president makes claim that Man City play â€˜prehistoricâ€™ football
Contents: Atletico Madrid president Enrique Cezero has claimed that Manchester City play â€˜prehistoricâ€™ football following their clash last night. City won their Champions League quarter-final tie 1-0 on aggregate as Atletico were unable to find a goal at the Wanda Metropolitano on Wednesday evening. Manchester City were battered and bruised but came through it In the first-leg, Atletico were heavily criticised for their tactics after failing to have a shot on goal in the whole game. However, it was City, who are widely recognised as one of the best footballing teams in the world, who put in a solid defensive display to progress through to the semi-finals. Now, Atletico president Cezero has slammed City for their approach to the game, labelling their style as â€˜prehistoricâ€™. Speaking to Marca (via the Daily Express), Cezero said: â€œIt was a match that, with a bit of luck, would have taken us to the semi-finals. We were not lucky enough to score a goal and reach extra time. â€œWe are a team that has a lot of status so that someone can offend us, and in the end, it has been shown that everyone has their prehistory. â€œWe played a good game, attacking and City yesterday played prehistory, defending and put a wall in front of their goal so they wouldnâ€™t score. Everybody has seen it. City was a completely defensive team. â€œIn the second half they shot on goal once. Yesterday it was shown that each one has their prehistory.â€ The game was also marred by a number of ugly scenes towards the end of the tie, as players from both sides clashed on the pitch, and then in the tunnel following the final whistle. Atleticoâ€™s players have been criticised for their behaviour but former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher believes it has been â€˜over the topâ€™. Writing in the Daily Telegraph (quotes via Metro), Carragher said: â€œIf there is one manager in the world I would love to see in the Premier League, it is Diego Simeone. â€œSimeone was always going to provide City with a physical and emotional challenge they rarely face in England. â€œThe reaction to Atleticoâ€™s performance was more over the top than anything they actually did. They were predictably aggressive and did as much as possible to prevent a free-flowing game. â€œBut there were no career-threatening two footed challenges, or incidents that qualify as cheating. â€œSimeone is box office. Win or lose, he guarantees a post-match debate. The criticism shadowing him and his team today reeks of hypocrisy. Why would anyone wish to sanitise every football game? â€œSimeone has fashioned a side in his image; warrior-like, edgy, determined to maximise discomfort. No team can play against Atletico without feeling they are going to have to earn their victory. â€œThere are plenty of Premier League clubs who could learn from that.â€
